title: United lifts ground stop after nationwide automation issues halted flights
text:
United lifts ground stop after nationwide automation issues halted flights Caption Delayed flights Jose M. Osorio, Chicago Tribune 
Travelers look at the United Airlines monitor for flight status near the economy check-in area of O'Hare International Airport as flights were delayed due to a stoppage. United Airlines grounded all flights in the United States because of "automation issues." Planes at O'Hare were not leaving the gates and some passengers said they couldn't book flights.

Osorio, Chicago Tribune) Caption Flying to Seattle Jose M. Osorio, Chicago Tribune 
United Airlines passenger Sarah Downing of Oakwood Hills was flying to Seattle with her family. Downing said that as she checked in, her flight was still listed as on time. 
United Airlines passenger Sarah Downing of Oakwood Hills was flying to Seattle with her family. Downing said that as she checked in, her flight was still listed as on time. (Jose M. Osorio, Chicago Tribune) 
A router problem was to blame Wednesday morning when United Airlines grounded hundreds of flights worldwide for nearly two hours, one of several high-profile technical glitches gaining widespread attention. Computer glitch halts all United Airlines departures 
United Airlines’ U.S. departures were halted for nearly two hours the morning of July 8, 2015, because of a computer fault, the second such setback for the carrier in less than six weeks. (Bloomberg)

The New York Stock Exchange stopped trading in the late morning Wednesday because of a technical issue, though shares continued to trade on other exchanges. The exchange said on its official Twitter feed that the issue was internal and not related to a breach of its systems. And the Wall Street Journal’s website, WSJ.com, was also down. There were no reports the issues were related. 
“We’re over-reliant on these systems,” said Joseph Schofer, a professor of civil and environmental engineering at Northwestern University who studies transportation. The technology allows companies to be more efficient, but they can be sensitive, he said. 
“It's critical that we step back and say, ‘How important is a failure, what’s the risk and how much should I invest in preventing it from happening.’”
